_header: As I lay in a winters night / In a darkening before the day
Title(s): disputisoun betwen þe bodi and þe soule
Subjects: body and soul, debate between; debates, body and soul; dialogues
_description: ‘þe disputisoun betwen þe bodi and þe soule’ — 61 to 74 eight-line stanzas (abababab) sometimes written as quatrains with medial rhyme

BodDig102.First Lines:
As I lay in a wynter nyȝtin a derkyng bifore þe
                    day…
BodDig102.Last Lines:
…But þe ioye þat þou hast to vs
                    wrouȝtgraunte vs for þy holy grace
BodDig102.Attributed Title:
disputacio inter corpus & animam (f. 136); Explicit
                        disputacio inter corpus & animam (f. 139v)
BodDig102.Editions:
Linow,  Wilhelm. 
             Þe desputisoun bitwen þe bodi and þe soule.
Erlanger Beiträge zur englischen Philologie
         1. Erlangen: Deichert, 1889; repr. Amsterdam: Rodopi, 1970: 1.24-105.

BodEngPoeta1.First Lines:
Als ich lay In Winteres nihtIn a droupnynge to fore þe
                    day…
BodEngPoeta1.Last Lines:
…Ac þe Ioye þat þu hast vs wrouȝtGraunte
                    vs god for þyn holy grace Amen.
BodEngPoeta1.Attributed Title:
A disputacion by twene þe bodi and þe soule (f.
                    286rc)

Scase,  Wendy,  and  Nick Kennedy, eds.  
             A facsimile edition of the Vernon manuscript: Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. Eng. Poet. A. 1.
         Oxford: The Bodleian Library, 2011.

BodLauMis108.First Lines:
[A]ls i lay in a winteris nyt in a dronkening bifor þe dayvor
                    soþe i sauȝ a selly syt a body on a bere lay…
BodLauMis108.Last Lines:
…Þo þat sunfol ben i rede hem red to schriuen hem and
                    rewen soreNeuere was sunne i don so gret þat cristes merci ne is wel
                    more
BodLauMis108.Note: Followed by a unique 4-line benediction in French.

BLAdd22283.First Lines:
Als ich lay In wintres niȝtIn a drounpnyng bi fore þe
                    dai…
BLAdd22283.Last Lines:
…Þat ich vsede in my ȝouþeHedde Ich holden whon
                    I was old…
BLAdd22283.Note:
Lines 1-198 only. Three folios missing following f. 80 (rubric roman
                    numeral foliation on the versos skips from ‘CClxj’ to
                    ‘CClxiiij’ on f. 81v).
BLAdd22283.Facsimiles:
Digital Facsimile of British Library MS Add. 22283 (‘Simeon’).
         2014; http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_22283.

BLAdd37787.First Lines:
As I lay in a wynteres nyȝtIn a droupuyng to fore þe
                    day…
BLAdd37787.Last Lines:
…And þe ioy þu hafte vs wrohtGraunt vs god for
                    þine holy grace. Amen
BLAdd37787.Editions:
Baugh,  Nita Scudder. 
             A Worcestershire Miscellany, compiled by John
                    Northwood, c. 1400, edited from British Museum MS. Add.
                37,787.
         Philadelphia, 1956: 107-21.
Garbáty,  Thomas,
                        ed.  
             Medieval English Literature.
         Lexington, MA, and Toronto: D. C. Heath, 1984: 603-19.

BLRoy18Ax.First Lines:
As I lay in a wynter nyght a litel dronknyng be fore þe dayMe
                    thoughte I sey a rewely syght a body þere it on bere
                    lay…
BLRoy18Ax.Last Lines:
…Þat þyn hand werk tyne nought In þy blisful stede a
                    placeÞe ioye þat þu to vs hast wrought þu grant vs for
                    þyn holy grace
BLRoy18Ax.Note: Two verse lines per manuscript line.
BLRoy18Ax.Attributed Title:
Explicit disputacio inter corpus et man (f.
                    66v)
BLRoy18Ax.Editions:
Varnhagen,  Hermann. 
             “Zu mittelenglischen gedichten: I-III.” 
             Anglia
         2 (1879): 225-55: 229-44.

NLS1921.First Lines:
As y lay in a winters niȝtIn a draupening bi for þe
                    day…
NLS1921.Note:
592 lines; most of f. 35 cut away, with loss of end-lines at
                    end.
NLS1921.Attributed Title:
Þe desputisoun bitven þe bodi & þe soule (f.
                        31vb)
